Award.AwardTitle: Career Development Workshop and Forum: Spring Technical Meeting of the Eastern States Section of the Combustion Institute, Columbia, SC - March 8-11, 2020

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award is to partially support the travel expenses of graduate and undergraduate students in attending the 2020 Spring Technical Meeting of the Eastern States Section of the Combustion Institute. This conference, to be held at the University of South Carolina, is a gathering of combustion researchers in academia, industry, and government from the East Coast region of the United States. The technical program of the conference consists of a series of plenary lectures, contributed oral presentations, workshops for young faculty/students, and information social gatherings. Experiences in attending technical conferences are extremely beneficial to students. These experiences will not only help with the students' professional development, but also stimulate their critical thinking in formulating future research directions.

Because of its effect on energy conversion and environmental quality, the understanding of combustion processes and practical combustion systems is of paramount importance to society. Exchange of information at conferences increases the rate at which research breakthroughs can be made to make combustion more efficient and cleaner with fuel-flexibility. A particular focus of this conference is on graduate and undergraduate students by providing an opportunity for these students to present and get feedback on their research. This award will be used to offset the travel expenses of non-local students in an effort to increase student participation at the meeting, particularly students from underrepresented institutions that may not have the financial means to fully support student travel to conferences and workshops.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 2020 Spring Technical Meeting of the Eastern States Section of the Combustion Institute was hosted by the University of South Carolina, in Columbia, SC, commencing the evening of Sunday, March 8, 2020 and concluding at noon on Wednesday, March 11, 2020.  This conference was a gathering of combustion researchers in academia, industry, and government from the East Coast region of the United States.  The technical program of the conference consisted of a series of plenary lectures, contributed oral presentations, and informational social gatherings. The Executive Board of the Eastern States Section always emphasizes that graduate and undergraduate students should be a major focus of the meeting and they are. Close to 90% of the podium talks are presented by the students.   

Under this project, workshops were organized tailored in developing the careers of graduate students who are pursuing a research career in combustion and energy science. At the conference two workshops were organized:

  • Panel format discussion session on how to formulate an effective career trajectory for academia, industry and national laboratory.
  • A workshop on career development was organized. The career development workshop was organized in a mentor-mentee format on ?Work Balance and Effectiveness?. At the same time, ?Diversity and Inclusion? was an additional topic of this workshop. The forum provided guidelines of best practices for mentors and mentees from under-represented groups in the combustion community.
  • The NSF support was utilized to offset travel cost of the graduate students attending the conference.

Major Activities:

  • Two workshops were organized and held at the 2020 Spring Technical Meeting of the Eastern States Section of the Combustion Institute designed for career development of graduate students.
  • A panel format discussion session on how to formulate an effective career trajectory for academia, industry and national laboratory was held during the afternoon session on the first day of the conference. The panel had representation from academia, national lab and industry and workshop was led by a moderator as the panel participated in the Q/A with the participating students. Dr. Jacqueline O?Connor (Pennsylvania State University), Dr. Francis Haas (Rowan University), Dr. Derek Splitter (Oakridge National Laboratory) and Dr. Paul Papas (United Technologies Research Center) represented academia, national lab and industry
  • The second workshop was held in a mentor-mentee format where smaller groups of mentee rotated around different discussion session where a 2-3 mentors led the discussion and mentoring session. The topic of discussion was ?Work Balance and Effectiveness? and ?Diversity and Inclusion. The forum provided guidelines of best practices for mentors and mentees from under-represented groups in the combustion community.
  • A survey was conducted to assess feedback regarding the workshops and also obtain suggestions to enhance these sessions in future meetings. The survey results are included as supplementary materials which includes view graphs and comments and suggestions from the participants.
  • The NSF funds were used to offset travel cost of 25 graduate students who participated in the entire conference (start to finish).
